bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilbur A. Sawyer, May 12, 1947

div1.p: Hench informs Sawyer about his efforts to memorialize Camp Lazear Building No. 1. He believes this is an opportunity to forge Cuban-American bonds. The Cuban government supports this effort, and the Mayo Clinic has pledged a financial contribution. Through Sawyer, [Hench] hopes to contact the Rockefeller Foundation in order to solicit their financial support.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilbur A. Sawyer, May 12, 1947
div1.opener:
May 12, 1947
Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer
49 West 49th Street
New York, New York
My dear Doctor Sawyer:
div1.p:
You may remember that I had the pleasure of meeting you in 1940 when
you and I spoke at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial at Washington-Jefferson
College. I do not want to presume on my brief acquaintanceship with you but I do
need your help and would appreciate greatly your advice on the following matter.

You may remember that in 1939 and 1940 with the help of Johnny Moran
(one of Walter Reed's guinea pigs) I rediscovered the lost Camp Lazear on the out-
skirts of Havana and found still remaining one of Walter Reed's experimental build-
ings--Building No. 1. It was my hope at that time to raise a modest amount of
money to enclose the building in a permanent protection and present it to the Cuban
Government. I had certain preliminary conversations with representatives of the
Cuban Government who were enthusiastic (?) about my suggestions and promised their
help. At first there was some opposition on the part of certain old-timers such
as the Finlay Institute and others to accept the identification of Camp Lazear but
Doctor Ramos, having asked me to submit a formal report, finally accepted this re-
port which is now filed in the Library of the Finlay Institute. In 1940 and 1941
I received letters from representatives of the Cuban Government indicating that
they had indeed accepted the authenticity of the site and the little shack.

Then came the war and my entrance into military service. In 1942 one
of the ranking Members of the Department of Sanitation of Cuba wrote me saying that
the Government was about to become genuinely interested in my plans to preserve
the site; but, after some correspondence from me, the matter was dropped. You know
the Cuban attitude of “manana.” To make a long story short, at long last the Cuban
Government has finally acted to make the shack a “national monument.” I have had
some correspondence from Johnny Moran and they finally seem quite interested and
excited about the project.

My original intentions and plans were modest. I had hoped to receive
perhaps ten thousand dollars from the Mayo Clinic and perhaps a similar amount from
the Rockefeller Foundation or a member of the Rockefeller family who might be in-
terested and willing to join in plans for a modest memorial. In 1942 the Mayo Clinic
did promise me that amount contingent on our raising other funds and contingent on
the promise of the Cuban Government to join with us in this venture, preferably to
add an equal amount to what the Americans give and to see to it that, after the
little memorial building was erected, it would be properly taken care of by the
Government.

Now to the point of this letter. Do you believe that Mr. John D.
Rockefeller, Jr. or a member of his family would be willing to join the Mayo Clinic
in starting the American part of the fund? I see no hopes of having the American
Government do anything and I have no interest in trying to collect nickels.
I do not know whether the Rockefeller Foundation would be able or willing to make
a contribution but certainly the Rockefeller Foundation, by its long interest in
the problem of yellow fever and through its many contacts with Latin America, would
be one of the institutions expected to be interested in such a project.

My motives in this matter are entirely unselfish. You are entirely
familiar with the unpleasant controversy as to the respective merits of Finlay and
Reed. By great good fortune it happens that on the very farm (part of which be-
came Camp Lazear) Finlay himself had done two or three of his inoculations years
before so that the San José Farm is most happily related both to Finlay and Reed.
By raising a suitable amount of American money for a modest “Cuban-American Medi-
cal Memorial” I believe we can heal the wounds and do much to stop this acrimonious
and undegnified debate. It would not surprise you I am sure to know that there
was a certain element in Cuba which was inclined to blame the Rockefeller Foundation
in part for ignoring givingWITHHOLDING credit toDUE Finlay. I am not mentioning this in an
attempt to influence the Rockefeller Foundation or any member of the Rockefeller
family but I am stating it as a fact and because of it it would be just all the more
gracious and appropriate if the Rockefeller family could join the Mayo Foundation
or Mayo Clinic in such a gesture of Cuban-American good-will.

Recently I was made a Member of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association and gave the enclosed report to them last October. This out-
lines the background and purposes of my project.

I expect to be in New York for three days from June 12th to 14th inclusive
just after the Meeting of the American Medical Association. Is there any possibility
that I might be able to meet, through you, Mr. Rockefeller or one of his agents to
explain in more detail my project. I would promise to make the interview a short
one. About two years ago when I was still in the army, friends suggested that the
United States Government's Department of Pan-American Cultural Relations might be
interested in this project--indeed it was suggested that this was “right up their
alley.” Therefore Surgeon General Kirk made an appointment for me to see Mr. Nelson
Rockefeller. Our interview was brief as, unfortunately, he had to tell me that his
department was folding up. I made no attempt to interest him personally.

May I state that within the last two weeks I have had two letters from the
heads of two government departments of Cuba expressing hope that my interest in
this project has been maintained. I have been told that the President of Cuba (him-
self a doctor) is greatly interested in the project and I have been lead to believe
that, if and when the matter is completed, the Cuban Government will participate
actively in the dedication and that the President of Cuba would be on hand with ap-
propriate ceremonies, etcetera, etcetera. I do know that when I was introduced
to President Batista four years ago he personally promised to do what he could and
to be at the dedication ceremony if and when the affair materialized.

Pardon me for making this letter such a lengthy one but it is not a matter
that I could discuss in a paragraph or two. I have no other possible contacts with
the Rockefeller Foundation or Rockefeller family and would greatly appreciate either
your direct help or such advice as you could give me. (Perhaps the current costs of
such a memorial would necessite a larger sum).
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer
-3-
May 12, 1947
P. S. You will note in the enclosed photostat of a recent newspaper clipping which
Johnny Moran sent me that the Cuban newspaper persisted in misinterpreting the facts
about Camp Lazear and the “Little Building No. 1.” The heading of the newspaper
photograph refers to the little building as the place where Finlay (not Reed) did
his work. This, of course, we can straighten out and my recent letters from the
Cuban officials indicate that they understand fully the nature of the little build-
ing.
